lg.l: Here you're all met, and look for a set speech,
Put into rhyme, to court you, and beseech
Your worships, but to hear and like the play,
But I, I vow, have no such part to say.
I'm sent a-wooing to you, but how to do 't,
I han't the skill; 'tis true I've a new suit,
And ribbons fashionable, yclept fancies,
But for the compliments, the trips, and dances,
Our poet can't abide 'em, and he swears,
They're all but cheats; and sugared words but jeers.
He's harkening there: and if I go about
To make a speech, he vows, he'll put me out.
Nor dare I write ye: therefore in this condition,
I'll turn my courtship into admonition.
When a good thing is proffered, don't be nice,
Our poet vows, you shan't be proffered twice.

div.head: The persons of the comedy.
div.p: Sir Val. Thrivewell, his uncle that adopted him heir.
Saleware, a citizen and a cuckold.
Bellamy, a woman disguised, and his steward.
Wat, a blunt fellow, Careless's servingman.
Mrs. Crostill, a rich vintner's widow, and humorous.
Closet, an old crone, nursekeeper to l. Thrivewell.

div.head: Scene. i.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Thou hast delivered my letter?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Yes sir, to Mr. Saveall your uncle's friend: but he has stood your friend so long, and so often, to so little purpose in moving your uncle for you, that he holds it utterly in vain, to urge him any further, he told me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Thou shouldst ha' told him, I would not be so answered.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Yes; and than he would have told me, let your master take his course.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Then you should ha' told him again, I have taken all the courses I could, or as any gentleman can to maintain myself like one; but all my courses are run out, and I have not breath, nor know any ground whereon to begin a new one, unless that thing my uncle sets me
up again, nor have I any means to attain to that, but by his mediation.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Then would he ha' told me again, what all your courses have been. Namely, running into debt by all the ways can be imagined, and cheating by all could be invented, then that the said thing, (As you call it) your uncle, before he cast you quite off, had redeemed you out of prison, and several holds, within the space of 15. Months 14. times.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That was not once a month then, or if it had, what had that been to him? 'twas I that suffered, thou shouldst ha' told him, not he.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: He would ha' told me then again, that several redemptions, cost your uncle at least 2000 l. And that upon your last revolt when he quite gave you over for a castaway, two years since, he cast the third thousand with you, upon condition never to afflict him more. And then he married in hope to get an heir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I that marrying spoiled all.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Because you should not after his death cast away all the rest of the thousands, and ten thousands which you might have lived to inherit, if your uncle's love or Mr. Saveall's counsel could have prevailed with you against the devil, and debauchedness.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Pox on't, let it all go, let that wretched uncle go, and let Saveall go for a punctual ass as he is. I confess he has by his saving help pieced me with my uncle a score of times at least. What had once more been to him?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Sir, it were better for you to think upon some course by ourself, and me your creature (That have stuck to you, or followed you through all fortunes) to maintain rich lace, and bravery upon you. And think in time too before this be worn out, upon some new ways for your supplies —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I cannot, nor will I trouble my brains to think of any, I will rather die here in ram alley, or walk down to the temple, and lay myself down alive, in the old synagogue, cross-legged among the monumental knights there, till I turn marble with 'em. Think quoth 'a I what should I think on?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: On your poor whore sir (As you have brought her) she's in worse case than yourself; your clothes are good enough —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I there's the devil. I would do something for her if I knew how. But what have I not done that can be done by a forlorn heir?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Why though the dice, and all other household games, and all the cheats belonging unto them have failed you by your and their discoveries, till none dare venture so near you as a man hurls a die or skirrs a card. Though all your hidden ways in Hyde-park races are trod out, and all your bowling booties beaten bare off of the grounds and allies; and the sweet honeycombs of all your cockpit cozenages cut off. Though all your arts of borrowing are crossed out of all men's books before you offer at 'em, while your old debts stand fairly written, and all your marts miscarry of putting out for credit, venison to citizens, or early cherries, codlings and apricots to their wives avail you nothing, cannot something yet be found?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing. All projects are confounded.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Did your father leave you nothing but wit to live upon for this? And did he leave you that but for years, and not for life? and is the term expired?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Hold thy peace. I am casting for something to be done by me, that shall be worth, and cost my life, to shame my uncle.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p:
There's a plot! Think of your poor whore sir,
how shall she live, if you cast away yourself?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I must leave her once thou knowest.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: If you could leave her now, and betake yourself handsomely to other women, I have thought on a course.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What, quickly, what is't?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: To set up a male bawdy house.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Fie upon't.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: You are handsome, lovely, and I think able to do one man's work, two or three such gentlemen more which I know, and can describe to you, with the ways I'll find to bring in custom shall fill your purses —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And empt our bones. I ever had enough of one mistress variety would destroy me. No gentlemen can be able to hold it out. They are too weak to make common he whores.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: For a little while sir, till we have got a stock of rich clothes; and than we will put draymen, and wineporters, Cornish wrestlers and such like into those clothes; and make them country cavaliers. Have you not seen course snout-fair drudges, clapped into bravery, that would do more bodily service in a brothel than twenty ladies' daughters? They are the game-bears of a bawdy-house, can play ten single courses for a clean-bred gentlewoman's one, we will hire fellows for groats a piece a day, that shall (Without the additaments of Clary, caudle or cock-broth) get us forty pieces a man before night, or perhaps a hundred by next morning, out of such she ▪ customers, as an aunt of mine shall find out for us.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O base villain! No I'll never fall so deep below a gentleman, as to be master of a bawdy-house.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Very good decayed gentlemen have done a much; though I urge this, but for your pastime sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No my first plot shall stand, I will do some notorious death-deserving thing (Though these clothes go to th'hangman for't, what care I) in defiance of him that was my uncle, and his methodical, grave, and orthographical speaking friend, Mr. Saveall that calls people pe-o-ple.

div.p: O Mr. Saveall how have you honoured me, how am I bound to you for this visit! Sir hearing that my uncle was come to town, and you with him, I did presume to write to you.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: Send forth your man.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Go forth —

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: One servant is not fit for all offices, although you keep no more; you presumed indeed, I can no less than call it a presumption, although it were but unto me you write; I speak not this in the behalf of any dignity in me; but that you should overween that I had ability to wrestle any more with your overgrateful uncle in your behalf. Therein was your outrecuidance.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: The miserablest man on earth! in having wearied out my worthiest friend, on whom the sum of all my hopes was cast.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: No, I am not wearied; but still in the same full strength: yet my modesty dissuadeth me from using strength above reason, and my reason prevaileth with me not to strive against a torrent.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: He is then inexorable, and I must perish. But did you try him for me this last time?

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: I have both tried, and tempted him to his vexation.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But did you urge that pious act of mine which he once vowed should never be forgotten, or unrewarded by him?

lg.l: Your standing upon merit in that act
Perplexeth nature in him, and confounds
both your desert, and his benevolence,
And now since you have urged it, I'll tell you,
Your act was undeniable, most noble,
And glorious in a nephew, greater piety
Could not have been expected in a son:
When from the swords of thieves and murderers,
Your valour rescued him — but —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I and my man I'm sure made four of the stoutest purses fly for't, that ever set our country of the score: after they had him down, and their points at his breast and throat, he crying out for help, when I came on by chance at a time too when I was in his displeasure, nay he hated me a whole year together before that, and yet I did it, and more than so —

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: Fare you well sir, I thought to have said all this for you, and more than so too. But —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nay sweet Mr. Saveall —

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: Good Mr. careless, as I can hear I would be heard sometimes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Indeed I cry you mercy, pray sir speak.

lg.l: I was commending of your act, and do so still.
You did express yourself in blood and nature
A perfect kinsman; and your piety
Drew blessings on you: for whereas before
Your uncle left you off to reprobation,
He then receives you a son, (Being his sisters.)
Adopted you, intended you his heir,
And out of his estate then presently
Allowed you two hundred pounds per annum,
And gave your man for what he suffered
In the conflict an hundred marks —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Poor rogue! and he deserved it, I'll be sworn for a thief's mark that he received; a cut of the coxcomb that cracked his skull, so that he could never bear his drink since, as he could ha' done before. For sir, as we
came in, I having put by the thrusts of three of 'em, the fourth man with a full blow —

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: Fare you well sir the second time —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nay courteous Mr. Saveall.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: I came to speak not with you altogether, but unto you for to be heard.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir I will hear you with all due respect.

lg.l: Your uncle having done so gratefully, and so plentifully for you.
You building still on merit for that service,
Did hold him so fast bound that you presumed
To run upon more extravagancies
In all the outways of debauchery,
Till for the one good deed you did for him
He did you forty, in restoring you
From surfeits, wants, wounds and imprisonments,
Till overborne with charge, and more with anguish,
At your outrageous, unexampled riots,
He gave you an irrevocable farewell, yet then at your departure. —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yet then I lived and could have done till now, merely by being his nephew, and supposed his heir, had not he married; but his marriage turned the hearts of all believing citizens from me, where before a tailor could have made me run through all the credit i' the town, when in a suit chinquant, and alamode they could inform themselves, whose heir I was, but to say truth I vexed him into wedlock, for before he valued not a wife at a bachelor's button.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: Farewell to you the third time.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir, you shall see me die first, and that instantly; that you may tell my uncle I'll be no more his trouble, or charge, unless in charity he'll send to bury me.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: You will not desperately work a violent end upon yourself?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No sir, the divills not so great with me; but my heart, I feel it ready to break. My uncle is no more my uncle, nor you my friend, all by my own fault, and what should I do here, but in to my bed, and out of the world presently. Wat. Wat.
I here sir!

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: I have dallied too long, and tempted him too far I fear.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Lay down my bed.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Your wench is come indeed, but I hope you will not to bed before he be gone.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Lay down my bed I say. But first unbutton me.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Lord how his heart beats! pangs of death I fear.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: Not so I hope. I will now come to the point sir, Mr. careless be comforted.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I am, and well resolved, I thank my better angel.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: Your uncle's friends with you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Alas, how can that be?

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: I thought your spirit had been higher.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: It will be sir anon, I hope.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: I have but dallied with you to search your temper.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: But you have searched too deep I fear sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Ah! —

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: Your uncle is friends with you, I say so far as to make a further trial of your nature, you may be yet his heir; for your aunt despaireth of any child by him, having fruitlessly been married now these two years.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Ah! — but good sir, can this be?

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: It is, and I will bring you to him. And see that all be well.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Your noble friendship hath revived me sir, oh run and fetch my cloak.
Tell Phebe I cannot stay to give her any satisfaction now, I must go see my uncle first.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: Poor gentleman, how weakly he standeth! The sight of his uncle will recover him. Come Mr. careless let us go.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir what do you think if I should first according to the reformation of my mind cut off my undecent hair, and change this garish apparel for a civil well worn students suit, I can be fitted presently hard by.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: No, the mind reformed is enough, your habit well becometh you.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Now wit an't be thy will go with him. And I hope this will be his last hot fit of the uncle.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Your masters gone forth it seems.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Called by his fortune, he is so.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Shuns he the sight of me? I'll overtake him.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: O your patience sweet mistress Phebe, a little patience.
He's gone to be happy, and to make you happy. I dare promise you a satin Gowen within this seven-night.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: For let me tell thee mistress Phebe bright he's reconciled to his uncle knight.
Away pimp, Flamsted, I came to be serious with him, to let him know the miseries I suffer, by the wrongs he has done me, and that I can nor will no longer bear 'em.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Nor him neither will you? Take heed what you say madam Marion ▪

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: No nor him neither, you pandarly parasite, till he make his vows good, and me an honest woman.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: By’r lady, a shrewd task, and I fear an impossible work.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Sirrah, I will claw your ugly face till thou undertakest it with him, to make it easy.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I'll do you all the good I can,

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: O will you so?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: How desperately valiant a whore grows, when she is so poor that her clothes fear no tearing.
But by what means can you hope to bring this work about?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: You know I have a wealthy kinsman in the city.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: O Mr. Saleware, and he has a wife too that bears it up bravely.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Pimp impudent, shall I claw your face into blushes at my injuries, to be mocked out of my maidenhead, when I was upon a good match in the country; then with a promise of marriage, to be enticed from my friends into fool's paradise (That was a new title for the city) and here to be used, and abused from lodging to lodging, by him that now flies me, for the decays he hath brought me to? But my kinsman has money though I have none, and for money there is law to be found, and in a just cause he will not let me sink, he says: for I have told him all.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: But not the how many times, the whence, the where's, and the wherewithalls, I hope have you?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Sirrah, I shall show you and your master too a way to more civility, since I am thus abused, and slighted.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: You have schooled me handsomely, and brought me into sense of your injuries: you have been overwronged, but not overwrought, nor overworn, you do excel in beauty, strength and spirit, which makes you in your very anger now appear so lovely, that I profess myself your creature. What would a kiss of this fair hand now make me do, and of those lips what not?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Away you creature.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Leave these temptations; do not strike me too deeply in love with you.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Away you creature.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: 'Tis true I am your creature, as I am my masters; and sometimes the serving creature, breaks his fast with a bit off the spit before the same meat is served up to his master's table, but is never denied to dive upon his masters leavings, you cannot think what an appetite that frown gives me.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: You are no saucy rascal.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Good wit too! My appetite needs no sauce; nor shall you need to make use of law, or friend against my master, but myself.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Be ruled by me, if I do not lay you down, and join with you presently in a course that shall content you, then — hang me lady at your door. —

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: In the next room we shall find pen, ink and paper, you shall write him such a letter (As I will dictate to you) that shall so nettle him.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Nay I did intend to leave him part of my mind in writing before I went. —

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: O cousin, I want you. —

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: A pox of this interupting cuckold, he hinders all trading, but his wives, 'zounds I was going with full speed a tilt, as the learned say, had not this horn-head come, we had writ lines together should have put down Hero and Leander —
Hark you mistress Phebe, is this your kinsman that you told me, you had told all the business to?

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p:
Yes, sir, I am the gentleman, and she has told me so much, sir that I must tell you, to tell your master from me, and as I would tell him myself if he were here personally present, he is a most dishonest gentleman if he do her not lawful right by marrying her; and
that right I came to demand, and obtain of him, or to denounce the law against him.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: How happy are you, that you came short to tell him so, else he would ha' so beaten you, as never was citizen beaten, since the great battle of Finsbury-field.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Your great words cannot make ▪ me fear his blows (I am not dashed nor bashed) nor cross him out of my book, for fear of any such payment. I have him there for four score pound as you know, though you are pleased to forget me, but sapientia mea mihi stultitia tua tibi.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Cry mercy Mr. Saleware, is it you? I hope mistress Saleware is well, your most exquisite, and most courtly wife; the flower-de-luce of the city.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Well wag well, you must not now put me off with my wife, she's well and much respected; I come to speak of, and for my distressed kinswoman, her whom your wicked master has most wickedly dealt withal. He has deflowered and deluced her, and led her from her friends, and out of her country into fool's paradise — by making her believe he would marry her, and here he has put her on, and put her off, with hopes and delays till she is come to both woe and want; and (Which may prove her most affliction, if he be suffered to forsake her) she is with child by him.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Say you so, mistress Phebe? here's small show of it yet.

sp.speaker: Prentice
sp.p: Sirrah, I shall show you and your master too a way to more civility, if I be thus abused and slighted.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: By the way Mr. Saleware, how many children have you by your most amiable wife?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Sir, that needs not to fall by the way of our discourse.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p:
But by the way I speak of getting children. Or
I pray tell me, did not you correct one of her children once, for which your wife reprehended you, and bade you correct your own? And how then shall my master be sure that this (If it be one) is his?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: What an asinego's this? I shall find a time sir, to talk with your master. In the mean time I tell you that my kinswoman is a gentlewoman of as good blood as himself, and of the best in Herefordshire.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Yes, welsh-blood.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: And shall find friends that shall not see her abused by you nor him. There is law to be found for money, and money to be found for friends, and friends to be found in the arches, and so tell your master, come away cousin.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: But one word before you go sir, is this gentlewoman, (Who was but a country chambermaid when my master took her to his mercy) of such boasted blood, your cousin by your own, or by your wife's side I pray?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Sirrah, like a saucy companion as you are, though you meddle with me that am a common-council-man; I charge you meddle not with my wife, you have had two or three jerks at her.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I was warned before sir, in my own understanding: for she is for great persons.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Then know your distance sir.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Yet give me leave to wait you down sir, cud shoe did it tell it kinsman that it is got with Champkin.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: You are a pandarly rascal, and I'll be a terror both to you, and your patron.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: How can you think so?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p:
Think! I see't apparently upon your face, and hear it in your sighs, your broken sleeps tonight , when your own groans waked you, declared no less;
but had I had the power of some wives with their husbands I could have fetched it out of you waking once (I thank you) you took me in your arm, but when you found 'twas I you turned away as in a dream.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Sure you dream now, whence can this talk proceed else?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I must not give it over till I know the cause of your melancholy fit, do you doubt my duty, or my loyalty? perhaps you do, and so make me the cause of your affliction.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: May such a thought within me, stick me to the endless torments.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: 'Tis lately entertained, whate'er it be; you came heart whole to town, and jovial. Have you been drawn for security into bonds by any of my friends, for great sums, and forced to pay 'em?

sp.speaker: Thr ▪
sp.p: Fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Are any great friends of yours in question, attainted, imprisoned, or run away?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Pshaw.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Or are you further grieved about your nephew, careless? I thought that your friend Saveall, and myself had made his peace with you; and that you had sent for him, do you repent that?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: No, no, sweet heart, he shall be welcome. And pray let me entreat you make no further inquisition; if (As you suppose) there be a trouble in my thoughts, I shall soon pass it over.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Tell me, or I shall prove the greater trouble. I would those few examples of women, that could not keep their husband's counsels had been burned, and the woman too rather than I should be disinherited thus, and slighted by a husband —

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Nay then you'll grieve me indeed.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p:
There has been many examples of discreet women
that have not only kept their husband's counsels, but advise and help 'em in extremities, and delivered 'em out of dangers.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: I pray content yourself.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Be you content to tell me then what troubles you. And I pray you tell me speedily, now presently; or (Excuse me in my vow,) it is the last request that ever I will make to you, and the last question I'll ever ask you, and (The easier to get it from you) I promise you by the continuance of my faith to you (Which by this kiss I seal) be it a deadly injury to myself, I will forgive it freely; not be troubled at it.

lg.l: I shall do that now, which few wise men would.
But she's discreet, and has a fortitude
Above the boast of women; should that fail,
And this too weighty knowledge for a wife
Should prove a torment to her, I'm excused
She pulls it on herself, and for revenge
Should she against her protestation move it,
I am enough above her.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You are resolved it seems to keep your secret unto yourself, much good sir may it do you.

lg.l: No, you shall know it, sir, and (If unshaken
Now, in your love to me) the wonder of all wives
You're bound by a fair pledge, the kiss you gave me,
To be unmoved, and to forgive it though
It be a deadly injury to yourself;
It is, and 'tis a great one; and so great
But that you have sealed my pardon, the hid knowledge
Of it should feed upon my heart, and liver,
Till life were banished thence, rather than pull
Your just revenge upon me; yet you frown not!
But before I declare it to your justice,
Let me renew your mercy. Kiss.
And on this altar, which I have profaned
while it breathed sacred incense, now with penitence
Offer religious vows, never to violate
My faith or love to you again. One moreKiss.
Before you hear it: for if then you stand not
Firm to your mercy, it must be my last.
What do you but violate your love to me,
Now in your most unjust suspicion?
I'll trespass so no more; yet many husbands
(I wish they had my sorrow, and no less
Purposer to reformation) wrong their wives.
Leave these perambulations; to the point:
You have unlawfully lyen with some woman!

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: 'Tis said; and now your doom.

lg.l: Ha, ha, ha. Here's a business!
Would somebody heard you faith: nay of five hundred
That now might overhear us (I mean not only
Gallants, but grave substantial gentlemen)
Could be picked out a twelve good men and true,
To find you guilty, I would then condemn you,
But such a jury must be paneled first.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: And can you be so mild? then farewell thought.

lg.l: Thought of your mistress sir, and then farewell
My jealousy, for let me tell you sir,
That I have had an ache upon these brows
Since your last being in town. And since you have dealt
So faithfully as to tell me it is one,
(There's no more, is there?)

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: No upon my vow.

lg.l: Name me the woman: if it be the same
That I suspect, I'll never suspect more.
As faithfully as to my confessor;Light weight ▪
Saleware my silkman's wife.
The same I meant,
You're a fair dealing husband. On what condition?
Come this is merry talk. Prithee on what condition?
Only to bring good custom to her shop,
And send her husband venison (Flesh for flesh)
I did observe you bought all there last term,
And wished me to her shop, and Mr. Saveall
With divers others to bestow our moneys.
Troth she's a handsome one; prithee on what conditions?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Thou shalt know all to purge me of my folly.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Well said.

lg.l: After a costly, and a tedious suit
With many an answer no, and no such woman,
At length she yields for a hundred pieces;
Had 'em, and I enjoyed her once.
That was,
When you last term sat up all night, and said you sat up with the three lady gamesters.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: It is confessed.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Fair dealing still.

lg.l: But here was the foul dealing, and for which
I hate her now: I having paid so great a fine, and
Ta'e possession thought after to deal rent-free.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: A peppercorn a quarter, if she be pepper-proof.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: But she at my very next approach, which was but yesterday denies me egress, except I make it a new purchase at the same former rate, and so for all times after.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Troth 'tis unreasonable, a hundred pound a time? How rich would citizens be, if their wives were all so paid, and how poor the court and country! But husht, here comes Mr. Saveall with your nephew, I take it; a handsome gentleman, could he be so debauched?

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p:
Sir, I have brought you home a reformado ▪
and do entreat (For what I have said unto him, and he hath fairly answered unto me) that words may not by you be multiplied.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Not a word of unkindness, nephew, you are welcome, give me your hand. George, thou art welcome.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I shall be George of horseback once more I see. In all humility I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Nay now thou speakest, and lookest too tamely George, I would have thee keep and use the lively spirit that thou hadst, but not to let it fly at random, as it has done George.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir, I have learned now by the inconveniences I have met with, in those extravagant out flights, the better to contain it within the limits of your leave, and fair allowance hereafter.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Well said, and again welcome George. But (And this you shall give me leave to say Mr. Saveall) I remit your thanks for any inclination I had towards this reconcilement till I do you some further kindness; only you had good advocates, who pleaded friendly for you, Mr. Saveall, and your aunt there before she ever saw you whom you may thank.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: A man must be so tied now.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Pray take notice of her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I cannot use respect enough sir.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: I like that modesty.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: Doubt him in nothing, for he is come home.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Madam as you are my gracious patroness, and myself so all unworthy, my duty cheques me in my approach to you.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You are the more entirely welcome cousin.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: She kisses like an old man's wife, that is, as a child late starved at nurse, sucks a fresh flowing breast.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You must not sir be bashful.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: 'Twill less become me to presume good madam.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: George, here's a lodging for you in this house, and my table has a place for you, send for your man to wait upon you.
Have you what still?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes sir, an honest true hearted civil fellow he is, as I have managed him, he can say grace now.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: The world's well mended. Tomorrow you shall give me a note of your debts George, which I'll take order for, if I may presume you have any.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Some driblets sir, my credit has not lately wronged me much.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: You speak sententiously, for credit sought with tradesmen, than their wares are dearer bought; so gentlemen are wronged.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Then not to wrong ourselves, let's in to dance.

div.head: Scene i.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: All Cheapside, and Lombard street madam, could not have furnished you with a more complete bargain, you will find it in the wearing, and thank me both for the goodness of the stuff, and of the manufacture.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p:
But now the price mistress Saleware. I grant your commodity is good, the gold and silver laces, and the fringes are rich, and I hope well wrought. Has your man made a note of the particulars, and their princes, at
the rate of ready-money (For I buy so) and not as you would book 'em to an under-aged heir, or a court-cavalier to expect payment two or three years hence; and find it perhaps never. I come with here is one for tother.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I know your ladyship's payment such; and they are prized so madam to a farthing.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Let me see, broad plate silver and goldlace, 206 ounces half, and a dram, at five and ten pence the ounce. 60 l. 5 s. 3 d. ob. 4. five and ten pence an ounce is dear.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I protest unto you madam that parcel of lace for a bed as you intend it, was bespoken, and agreed for at six shillings the ounce by a very great person: but because ready money came not to fetch it off, fortune reserved it here for you, you could not have been so fitted on the sudden else within London walls; and I am glad the same fortune was so favourable to me, as by my hands to design it for your ladyship's use and pleasure. I hope madam we shall hear of a young heir a coming shortly, and that will make it a rich and fortunate bed indeed; and then sir Oliver would thank me too.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: What a bold slut it is, well then the rest of the particulars here of laces, and fringes, loops, and buttons, makes the sum of all an hundred pound eight shillings four pence, halfpenny. I am no good arithmetician, but if any be overcast, and overpaid, you must allow restitution.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Yes, good madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Is all put up into this box?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: All madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Give me my purse. Take you home that while I make payment for it; your goldweights mistress Saleware.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Here madam all in readiness.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You take no gold but what is weight I presume.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: 'Tis but light pains to weigh it madam. But let me save your ladyship that labour.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Nor shall it be your trouble, command your servant I pray for a glass of your beer —

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Some beer for my lady presently.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: That I may tell you in more privacy, what perhaps you would not have him hear: for prentices though they are bound to keep their masters secrets, are not all privy to their mistresses; that's more a journeyman's office.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Your ladyship is pleased.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Not very well with myself, for I have gone beyond my commission in this bargain, and exceeded my husband's allowance. Here's one hundred pounds eight shillings 4 d. ob. in the bill, and he allows me but the bare hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: The odd money is but a small matter madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: A great matter in an honest poor country lady's purse, may serve her a whole Christmas at post and pare, or farthing gleek, when the gay gamester's wives o'the city may command the hundreds, out of the purses of such poor ladies husbands. But here is the odd money, eight shillings four pence, half penny, and so all's paid.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: What means your ladyship?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Do you not understand me then? I'll tell you that which I thought fit to conceal from your servant; and from your husband too had he been here, perhaps he knows not on't. My husband left with you, or lent you the last term a hundred pound, which he assigned to me; and now I have it in commodity. Had you forgotten it, when it was to do you a good turn, when your absent husband failed you, and you wanted it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: A good turn madam?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Yes, was it not to have the free use of a hundred pound ready money, a whole quarter of a year, through a dead vacation, and at last to take it out in wares? A good turn I think for a trades-woman; take heed you do not by your sullenness make me suspect another kind of good turn, or that you did my husband any to my injury, nor deny the receipt of his money, lest I take up a violence that will not become me, nor you be able to bear. Be therefore well advised both in what you say, and who hears me. Somebody comes.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Madam your beer.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I'll pledge you mistress Saleware.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I shall presume then madam — drinks.

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: This was right cast, was it not friend?

sp.speaker: Prentice
sp.p: Your ladyship will find it so — la. Drinks.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: And I hope you will find your money so well bestowed madam, that you will vouchsafe always to know the shop.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Ever upon the like occasion, mistress Saleware, so most kindly farewell sweet mistress Saleware.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: The humblest of your servant's madam. Open the boot for my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: 'Tis done my coachman does it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I would the devil were in your coachman's coat to take his carriage for his pains.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: One word more mistress Saleware, can it be he?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Lay your commands on me good madam.

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Not to your trouble, I perceive a young gentleman attends for conference with you. Is not his name Fitzgerrard?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: No madam, his name is Bellamy, much depending on the young lord lovely.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p:
I thought I had known him, he is a handsome youth. I cannot blame you now with him: but beware
of old knights that have young ladies of their own. Once more adieu sweet mistress Saleware.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Most courteous madam — and once more to the devil. But on my life her chaste ladyship is taken with this beardless Bellamy. How she shot eyes at him!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Now may your servant obtain a hearing lady.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: My ears are open sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: But you are sad or angry, why seems that brow to threaten a subjection over him that is your vanquished captive; or has Cupid placed his bow there bend at me, whose heart already lodges all his arrows, never to be restored but by your pity?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Fie, fie upon't! what talk is this? I am vexed, and you would mad me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What has displeased you?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: A cross business that has happened in my shop today, I being none of the wisest chapwoman, have undersold a parcel of the best commodities my husband had. And should he know't we should have such a squabble.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Husband's should be so served that do impose those mercenary offices on their wives.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Talk so, and I will hear you, your amorous notes sound like play-speeches.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Servile, nay slavish offices, ranking their wives with their prentices.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: They pretend only that we should overlook our servants, when they but set us there for show to draw in custom: but in making us such overseers they are overseen themselves; shopkeepers-wives will be meddling and dealing in their kind, and as they are able, as well as their husbands (Some much better, and more profitable) but I was overreached I confess.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: For no great matter I hope.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: No, the matter was not much (That never fretted me) but the manner has e'en killed a she shopkeeper. I cannot be long-lived, here under a penthouse, as my lord (You know) told me when he said he would shut me out of this servitude, and that I should change my coat, though my husband could not, before he were an alderman, and be ranked with ladies.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My lord has still the same regard of you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: So it appears by the tailor and the mercer, whom he sent four days since to measure me out, and suit me to his honour, and no return of them found, yet his land might ha' been measured all and sold, while a poor suit is dreamt on, had he born the mind of some lord?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I doubt not but this paper will clear that jealousy. And while you read I'll speak that which I dare not utter through, sighs and blushes to an entire attention.

lg.l: I am of noble-blood myself, freeborn,
And not without good education;
But since I am engaged in this employment,
And made an instrument of others lust,
I find myself a scandal to my name,
To honour, and to virtue, the base blot
Of Pandar sticking on me. But not this ▪
Alone is my affliction. Here's my torment,
That while I do true service to my lord
(Whom I must ever honour) in my agency
Unto yourself (Whom I cannot but love)
I find myself a traitor to his trust,
In my negotiation for myself.
Nor can I find it possible to desist,
Mine own attempts, to you, or forbear to urge
Your constancy to him.
How easy a work
'Twere for one woman to supply 'em both,
And hold her husband play to level acoile,
A wooden two-leaved book, a pair of tables
Would do't.
How wretched is that suppliant, who must make
Suit to obtain that, which he fears to take!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: At the bear at the bridge-foot six o'clock , good.
Sir, I find my lords honourable appointments here, and have heard you all this while.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Now I could wish, and was in hope you had not.

lg.l: I will not blame you on your lords behalf;
Because you have enough rebuked yourself.
But sir, if you presume upon the favour
I give your lord, and therefore to obtain me,
'Cause I am his, you undervalue me
To think that I can stoop unto his servant,
Though almost his companion, you may think
After that degradation by degrees,
I may, in time, descend unto his footman, I'm no cast
Garment of his lordships yet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You have schooled me fairly, I am humbled, lady —

lg.l: D'ye hear, d'ye hear sir, Mr. Bellamine,
One word before you go.
What would he buy mistress? can you take his money?
Sir d'ye hear?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Pray attend you the tother end of th' shop, if I cannot handle a customer, why dos your master trust me? Could a frown fright you? Let a smile then cheer you.

lg.l: And that's a heavenly one,
As that of Cynthia at Endymion.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Pray leave your player-like passionate expressions ▪ and if you love me, like a man speak to me.

As I am a woman; are you silent? if you doubt the length of my man's ears at that distance, you may whisper what so? But that is a right shop-whisper indeed with tradeswomen that are handsome; is that the most you will give sir? Could I afford it so, do you think I'd make two words w'ye? yet this before you go — kiss. Now match it for the price I'll give it you for nothing.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I shall forget I have a lord. I must forget him here.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Do so, and if (I say) you love me, speak plainly what you ▪ would have me do, or what you would do with me (I love to daunt these young things that love before they can love to the purpose, or speak to't ▪ handsomely like a boy that would fain be shooting at wildfowl, before he knows how to discharge a birding-piece) I would hear you speak, you have often muttered and fribbled some intentions towards me, but I would hear you speak. Come, if you love me lay by the fear of the lord that sent you, and tell me roundly now, what you would have me do?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I would entreat you —

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Well; what?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: That you would be pleased —

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: With what? or to do what?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: To wear this pair of silk stockings for me ▪

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Is that all your suit, 'tis granted, with my thanks to you; have you no more to say?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes, I say you are the beautifullest of women; and that my lord in your enjoyment is the happiest —

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Nay think not of your lord, but ask me, something.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I would but dare not hope for such a favour, you'll never grant it, my unworthiness.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: How can you tell?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You will not wrong my lord, so as to do it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Not in his sight perhaps. What is it? come.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: It is —

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: It is then, let it be so. Go to school child.

lg.l: It is — that you would, let me — give you this ring,
And grace it with your finger.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Will that be a wrong to your lord?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes, to wear any favours, but his own.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Dos he know this?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No, nor I would not that he should (And given by me) for all the rubies in Cheapside, where I bought this but now, over the way.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Come sir, I'll dally w'ye no longer, I know what you would have with me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And now you will betray me: I am shamed then and undone.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: No, but I have you o' the hip. 'tis plain you would lie with me: deny it if you can.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: O dear, did I say so now?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: What need you when I know it, you would lie with me, and you shall. Take courage man.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: But, in good earnest, shall I? shall I?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Yes, in good earnest, you'll find it no trifling business, when you come to't once. But sir, upon condition.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Any condition lady.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: All purpose on't is lost, and all comes out else.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Name your condition, I'll perform it if it be in the power of my life.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: You saw here at your coming a fair lady.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I took no notice of her.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: But she did of you, she is called the lady Thrivewell.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Sir Oliver Thrivewell's lady?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: The same, you have known her it seems.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Seen her before she was married.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I will be brief with you, as you love me she loves you as eagerly, but with much more boldness, you saw her whisper me, and how loath she was to depart, when her eye was upon you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I did observe it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: She is my noble friend, and the sweetest lady, I need not set her out. But though you think you suffer in your honour, in being an instrument twixt your lord and me, with the base blot of pander sticking on you, (These were your words) I have engaged myself for her to be your pandaress; be so, I shall be even with you in business if you account it so.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What d'ye mean lady?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: To urge against myself, for that sweet lady, which no woman else I think would do, that loves you so unfeignedly as I. But 'tis my fate, and the injunction I must lay upon you, to make me yours. That first you give yourself to her embraces; I'll give you means for your access to her, and your success with her, which done, and on your faith affirmed to me, 'tis so, I will perpetually be yours more freely than your lords.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You urge this but to try my constancy.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: For that I'll satisfy you soon, my husband coming we must tonight at the bear —
My lord writes so.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: And there I will direct you in your progress.

Ally how dost? Mr. Bellamy how is't? How dos my noble lord? You are sad methinks. Have you overbought any thing here, and so repent your bargain? Or cannot my wife, and you agree upon't ▪ you must use Mr. Bellamy
kindly my sweet Ally: he is our noblest lords most special favourite, and must find all fair dealing here, as well when I am abroad as at home sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You hear not me complain sir, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: What an asinego's this! He might ha' thanked me for my good words, though I meant him no good will, I hope thou hast overreached him indeed.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Thomas your hopes are vain, Thomas in seating me here to overreach, or underreach anybody . I am weary of this mechanic course Thomas; and of this courser habit, as I have told you divers and sundry times Thomas, and indeed of you Thomas that confine me to't, but the bound must obey.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Never the sooner for a hasty word, I hope sweet Ally; not of me nor of my shop I prithee at seasonable times love. But for thy habit (Though this be decent on a citizen's wife) use thine own fancy, let it be as courtly, or as ladylike as thou pleasest, or my lords desires.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Then I am friends again.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Troth, and I'll call thee friend, and I prithee, let that be our familiar and common compellation: friend it will sound daintily, especially when thou shalt appear too gallant to be my wife.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Then let it be so friend.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Intruth it shall, and I am very much taken with it. Friend I have found a customer today that will take off my rich parcel of broad bed-lace, that my lord Paylate bespoke, and left on my hands, for lack of money.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I have sold it already friend, with other laces at a good rate.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: And all for ready money friend?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Yes friend, a hundred pounds, and somewhat more.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Who would be, or who could live without such a friend, in such a shop? This money comes so pat for a present occasion, to stop a gap. It has stopped a gap already friend.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I have disposed of the money, the odd hundred pound for apparel, friend, and other accommodations for myself.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Never the sooner for a hasty word I hope friend.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I have done it friend, whereby to appear more courtly, and ladylike as you say, to gain you more custom to your shop.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Uuch friend — is it so?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: And friend you must not be angry, or think much of it, if you respect your profit friend.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: I were no friend but a wretch if I would. No let it go friend, and — sapientia mea mihi is my word, I must not grudge at my friend in any thing.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Then friend, let your shop be your own care for the rest of this day, I have some business abroad.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Whither sweet friend?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Is that a friendly question?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: I am corrected friend, but will you not take a man to wait upon you?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: To watch me, shall I? and give you account of my actions? was that spoke like a friend?

lg.l: I am again corrected friend,
Do your own pleasure, you'll return to supper.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Yet again?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: And again, I am corrected friend?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Neither to supper, nor to bed perhaps.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Never the sooner for a hasty word I hope.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: But if I chance to stay, you cannot be a faithful friend and ask me where, or in what company, friendship you know allows all liberty.

lg.l: Sapientia mea mihi. A witty wife, with an imperious will,
Being crossed, finds means to cross her husband still;
And tradesmen that so match, must not with gall
Temper their wives, but sweetly by witall.

div.stage: Enter careless, with two letters in his hand, and what with a candle, and wax.

lg.l: Dos not the world come finely on, wat, ha?
And have not we convenient comings in already, ha!

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Better then we know how to have paid, for that's the glory on't.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I need no more ensconcing now in Ram-alley, nor the sanctuary of whitefriars, the forts of Fullersrents, and Milford-lane, whose walls are daily battered with the curses of bawling creditors. My debts are paid; and here's a stock remaining of gold, pure gold hark how sweetly it chinks.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Yes, and 'twill ring the changes shortly.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: For necessaries wat, for necessaries it shall change, and ring all out, and 'twil so long as I have an uncle, and know to manage him, let money fly,
I can no faster spend than he supply.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: For necessaries sir, but you must not now count sack and tobacco, whores and fiddlers in abundance, necessaries.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Why pray?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Because you'll have but little then for extraordinaries, that is to say in a gentleman for charitable, and pious works and uses.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: The fellow's spoiled.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p:
Not spoiled neither: for I would but wave your purpose of flying at all new game, and neglect your poor whore, who now begins to be so violent for
wrongs, she can no longer bear, that she intends to pursue you with her complaints hither to your uncle's house.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: My uncle's house? my house. Is not the first morning's draught mine?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: With great reason, for you are first dry in the morning.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Is not the question first asked me, what will you have to breakfast? what will please you for dinner, and what for supper? Has not my uncle let out moneys, and taken bonds and mortgages in my name? do not his tenants crouch to me, and his servants all call me young master? And dos not my uncle take care to marry me to ten thousand pound, and a thing like a wife?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: You have got a brave possession here, I must needs say; and I applaud your fortune most in this, that your young aunt the noble lady here, who you see feared would prove a cruel stepdame to you, appears to be more friend to you then your uncle. 'tis a most gracious sunshine in her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: She shall lose nothing by't. I have thought a way to requite her.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: But sir, for mistress Phebe, will you take no order for the poor soul?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I do not like your zealous solicitation, but here's an order for her, in answer of her malapert letter you brought me last night. Give it her, and these five pieces upon condition that she never come, write, or send to me again, till I send to her.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: That's somewhat hard sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nay look you what, you are a little mistaken in me. I must give over whoring, for special causes there unto me moving.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p:
O now I find you. And 'twere richly worth
your patience, if you could win the widow by't, for whom you stood in fair election once, until your last debauchment.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I shall stand fairer for her sir, when I leave working but a week or two, shall I not?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Yes, if you leave it quite, but to forsake her whom you have brought low, to fall to others, were such a thing —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Well sir, it may be I will, it may be I won't, what's that to you? carry you the letter, and the money, and try how that will work with her.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I'll do my best, but if she should exclaim, and bring on her cousin Mr. Saleware to be clamorous —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Her cozen's a cuckold, exclaim and clamorous! give me my money again.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Nay I am gone sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: The rogue's in faction with 'em; oh noble Mr. Saveall, you have most fairly kept your minute with me, I have written my letter, sealed it and all, here to the widow.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: So early? that is well.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I have written no less than six large epistles this morning, and sent 'em now by my man to be conveyed into the country to lords and knights, with all the news spiritual, and temporal, foreign and domestic that could possibly fall into a private gentleman's collection.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: With such dexterity, that if I would make a trade on't, I could undo all the news-mongers in town that live by't.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p:
It is a most commendable practice in a gentleman, and it will mature your judgement in the both
commonwealth and state affairs, and in short time invite you unto the chair of helm.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: When I am once married, and settled, you shall see what an ass 'tis, he believes me.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: How am I comforted in my meditation for you, and how overjoyed will your uncle be at the use you make of your retirements!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I confess it is (By reason of my unwontedness to it) some difficulty for me to write to women; wherefore since you have so nobly undertaken the conveyance of this, let me beseech you to apologise for the rudeness of my style.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: To the fair hands of the most accomplished in virtue mistress Anne Crostill, present, I pray with my service; the outside hath no rudeness on it, and (I doubt it not) she shall find within all sweetness and urbanity.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: As you may interpret it to her sir.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: Sir, what I have already said, and do intend to say unto her from your uncle, and myself on your behalf, together with what you have here written, shall (I doubt it not) prepare so fair a way of proceeding for you; that at your visit of her you may say, veni, vidi, vici, she is your own.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And then — a ha, Mr. Saveall!

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Expect your fortune modestly, and when it comes embrace it with discretion.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir, I am edified.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: It is well if you be so; I will put my undertaking in action presently, pray for my good success.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
I dare not tell him now I cannot; but I wish well for the moneys sake; and let the vintners pray, and all the decayed sparks about the town, whom I will raise out of ashes into flame again. Let them pray for my good wokes. O my young lady ants grave waiting
woman. If she were not hers, and out of this house I should take her for a bawd now. But being hers, and here how much may I mistake? all flesh is frail.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Not to disturb your morning meditations, my lady has sent you —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And you have brought me, what sweet mistress closet?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: A part of her ladyships own breakfast, it is very cordial and comfortable to the spirits, I assure you, and delectable to the younger sort, and profitable to the old.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: One of Robert Greene's works, or the mad doctor that preaches boiled in't I think.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: 'Tis a composition of mine own sir, of many excellent decoctions, of most wholesome restorative, and costly ingredients.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That it was sent by her makes it more excellent, whose bounteous care of me, I must acknowledge exceeds all cost in carving to me, and countenancing me at her table, in gracing me in presence of the ladies that come to visit her; in giving charge for decency in all things for my chamber, my fires shining, my odours burning, my livery served in, my soft and costly bed prepared and spread with perfumed linen — here's ambergris in this now —

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: O is it so, do you find that?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But though she is my own uncle's wife, I could e'en say 'tis pity a young man had her not.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: What a wag's this?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: She is a most sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p:
She is a sweet lady indeed, I can best speak
it that have known her from the womb hitherto: a sweet infant she was born, and a sweet babe I swaddled it, and a sweet child I nursed it, I trained it up a sweet child. It was in manners a sweet child, at her book and sample a sweet child. I never whipped it but once, and then it was sweet too, and sprawled but a little, and whimpered but a little it was so sweet a child; and so she grew upwards, and upwards towards woman, and a sweet youngling she was, and so grew upwards and upwards towards man, and then a sweet bride she was, and now a most sweet lady she is, (As you say, and I commend you for it) and so she stands at a stay. For now she grows no more upwards then upon her wedding day, not upwards as I would have her upwards, here I mean young gentlemen, could I but see a sweet babe of hers once by my master, I could be then content to sleep with my ancestors.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I had rather see your gibship hanged up with polecats in a warren, and your sweet lady with you, though I confess that were some pity. I hope her barrenness, or his will preserve her from my curse.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: I hope still, and she hopes still; and I make him of this broth for every morning, and many other good strengthening things (I cannot say for the same purpose) for I shall never see him have an heir by her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Excellent! that's best of all.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Because you then are heir, say you so? Is that your love to your aunt?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No I protest nurse, I meant by the broth, the bottom was the best of all.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Then I cry mercy.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Cannot all thy art, and her cost find help for my uncle, think'st thou, to get a child?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p:
Help! what d'ye mean. He might have help
and helps enough, were she not too virtuous.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Still thou mistakest me nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Away wag away, your aunt loves you too well to think so of her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nurse as I hope to inherit any thing hereafter —

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: I should but serve you well to tell her your good thought of her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nurse, by this good — piece I think no harm.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Nay, nay.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Take it I say. And tell her if thou wilt, that I love her so well, that were she not mine uncle's wife, I would get her an heir myself rather then be his.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Kind young master, now I am heartily sorry that I moved you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And for my uncle were I his heir apparent, I rather wish he might live till all this world were weary of him, and the next afraid to take him.
Then I survive him (Tongue, a pox punish you for lying)
Now I live well, and merrily good nurse,
Wealth and estates, bring cares and troubles with 'em,
Were all young heirs of my contented mind,
Parents and patrons would be better prayed for.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Good gentleman.
Nurse closet.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: O my lady calls.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Present my thanks and best respects unto her.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: I should ha' told you first — I ha' forgotten. My head is naught,

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What member hast thou good then?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: My lady desires you — this talk has put me out — oh this head! My lady desires you —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Desires she me nurse?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Yes sir, she desires you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Refuse me if I desire not her as much, for all she is my uncle's leavings.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: My lady desires you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And she shall have me nurse — and she were ten uncle's wives, and she ten of mine ants.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: O this head! nay now you will not hear me, she desires you to go abroad in the coach with her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Any whither, to Islington, Newington, Paddington, Kensington, or any of the city outleaps (I know 'em all) for a spurt and back again, tell her I am up and ready for her, and could ha' been without her stirrup porridge, though I thank her for her care. A man can not be too well prepared, or provided for so sweet a lady, in so much distress. A very Andromeda, chained to a rock.

div.stage: Takes up his cloak and sword ▪

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: What's this you say? I understand no word of it, I would take your answer right, though I faltered in my lady's message.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: The devils in this overruning tongue of mine, I could find in my heart to worm him out with my teeth.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: What must I tell my lady sir?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That I am more obliged to her ladyship then I was to my mother, she has brought me a new man into the world, and that my being and my life is hers.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I hope he's a true convertite, did I send you to hold discourse here, closet?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Nor did I madam but I could hear this gentleman a whole day methinks. He speaks so acknowledgingly of your ladyship's virtue, and goodness towards him.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I am beholding to him, will you go with me nephew to the exchange? I am to buy some toys there for the country, you may get a fancy by't.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Good, I must wear her favours.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Or cannot you forbear your study so long?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: To do you service madam, under whose commands I build my happiness.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Be not at the distance of compliment with me good nephew.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I would not be thought insolent dear madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Come the coachman grumbles at my stay, and 'twill be dinnertime presently, so the cook will be angry too.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You are all tenderness to your servants madam.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: A sweet gentleman, and bountiful, if my lady had been blessed with such a husband, what a place had I had!

div.head: Scene i.
div.stage: Enter Crostill reading a letter, Saveall.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Do you know the contents Mr. Saveall of the familiar epistle you have brought me here?

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: No lady, but I guess it a fair expression of the writers affection to you, although he desired me to crave your pardon for the rudeness of his style, it being the first that he hath composed of that consequence.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I'll trust you sir, with the full knowledge of it, pray read it yourself.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: I find she is pleased, and my endeavour prosperous, for the young gentleman, I am sorry that I delayed a day in the delivering of it.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Pray read it out sir, for I find it so pleasant that I could hear it a whole day together.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: In the first place you shall give me leave to wonder at your impudence (Though it be but in your dreams) to have a thought that I ever intended, or can be drawn by persuasion, force, or the power of witchcraft to marry you —
Bless me! sure if he writ this, the devil dictated to him.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: On sir, that's but his first charge.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: Secondly, I am to tell you, that I am warm in mine uncle's favour. And 'tis not a piece a time, or five pieces for a piece of pleasure can undo me; and so I can have change, and scape the captivity of wedlock.
This could no otherwise be done but by the devil that ought him the shame.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What follows I pray, there's the first and second point passed? mark his method.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: Thirdly, and lastly, let me advise you, since you are so hot upon marriage, though I assure myself you love none but me, (And I thank you for't) that you frame or dissemble an affection to some one of the city, who is but comparative to yourself in blood and fortune, and so you may make by-use of me as your friend, and have children like me,

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Have you ever heard so quaint a love letter?

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: Lady, the injury done in it, to yourself is unanswerable, but my wrong in being his messenger, I will make him answer.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Excuse me sir, he has done me a favour; I pray inform him so with my great thanks. But for what you conceive a wrong to yourself, use your discretion, you have no more to say to me for him at this present, have you sir?

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: Not for him but against him, I will un say all that I said before intended for his good.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: But I'll not hear you wrong your former love, and judgement of him so, which made so deep impression here, that I had locked his love up as a jewel in my breast, and you in striving now to wrest it thence may break the cabinet; I rather wish you'll be a friendly means to draw his presence hither, that I myself may mildly question him.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: Are you serious lady?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I fear I shall not rest before I see him, but do not tell him that, lest in this sullen humour, he force his absence to afflict me more; I'll hold you sir no longer, deal for me as you can, I know you have a guess at my desire.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: I'll do you service in it.

I guess that her desire is to do some act of revenge upon him. And (So it be not mortal) it were but justice in her for so gross a scorn by him cast upon a well reputed gentleman. Yet is it observed in her that she has a violent humour to do, and not to do things oftentimes wilfully against all good council or persuasion, she has the spirit of contradiction in her, and an unalterable resolution upon sudden intentions, a most incorrigible will she has that will not bow nor break. This cross abusive letter therefore may do good upon her,
however mischievous he might intend it. If she meant well to him before, it may the faster bring her on, but it amazes me that he should write so, bearing his uncle, and myself in hand, that he so fairly loved her, and besought us to negotiate with her for him, should she forgive it, yet the wrong to us in his vile manners is unpardonable, and so sir, I come to you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O Mr. Saveall —

lg.l: What mischief or despite have I e'er done you,
That could provoke your desperate spleen against me,
To wound mine honour?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What do you mean good sir?

lg.l: You have employed me basely, made me your
Carrier of scandal, and scurrility to the hands
Of nobleness and virtue. Could the fiend
Lust that is in you suffer you to write
No other sense or language to a person
Of her fair name, and worth, than such as ruffians
Would send to strumpets? or it being such. Enter Wat.
Could not a porter, or your pander there
Serve for the lewd conveyance?
What a welcome's that!
You might safer
Have sent it so, and your own right hand with it;
Then to have drawn my just revenge upon you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Hold I beseech you, and sir, though I lose the widow by my error (Which was indeed but a mere accident) let me not be so miserable made as to lose you, before you hear a short examination —

lg.l: Delivered you the letter which I sent
Yesterday to the damsel that you wot of?
Yes sir, she read it, kissed it a hundred times,
Then made a bosom idol on't,
And says you are the noblest gentleman,
under a saint that e'er took care for sinner.
Hell take her for a mistaking whore,
She has the widow's letter, and the widow hers,
I found it sir, when you judiciously
Said it was ruffianlike, and strumpet ▪ language.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: How could you err so strangely?

lg.l: O slightly, slightly, curse of my heedless brain!
And then too be trapped with carelessness.
When I was so religiously resolved,
T'incline to virtue, and a marriage life,
Thinking with one hand to cast off my follies,
And to take hold of virtue with the other,
For sir, (I will confess myself to you)
The letter you conveyed was in defiance,
A loose lived wanton, intended to a whore,
That impudently hopes an interest in me.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: It was not so directed.

lg.l: I there was
(The hell confound it on't) my giddiness:
I sealed both letters ere I superscribed 'em,
And so gave each the contrary direction.
'Twas a gross carelessness, and if you lose
A fortune by't, do not blame your friends.
That fortune should favour a whore before
An honest woman. 'twas the sweetest letter,
The daintiest winning things — (The devils in't)
She must not carry't from the widow so.
Fetch me the letter again.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Do you think she'll part with't sir?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Cannot you beat it out of her sir?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I cannot tell how to do that.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Thus sir — I'll give you demonstration, you malicious rogue, you that conspire with her to betray me, so good a master I have been to thee, and so good a friend to her, I'll recompense you both.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: You have undone us both, and will discard us now you are warm in your uncle's bosom again — but —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But what you traitor you?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: You put me in good mind, and if I do not somewhat.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I owe you somewhat for your last-nights absence, too pernicious villain that kepst thyself out of the way of purpose that I should be drunk, and abuse myself, and the house here all lay of your absence, there's somewhat more for that.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: 'Tis all upon account sit.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Who knows an honest servingman that wants a good master.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Was it your man's fault Mr. careless? if I be not revenged etc.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No faith, to speak truth he was as much abused in it, as you in doing a thing as contrary to his vile conditions, as you did to your noble name. But I crave only your pardon, I know not what I do besides. This cross blow of chance staggers my reason so —

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Well sir, since I have found the error, my reason reconciles me to you, and since it grew out of your equal intent to cast off the evil, as to embrace the good, I will re-mediate for you to the widow.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But yet she'll know I have had a whore. Yet then you may say, 'tis such a running disease among young gentlemen, that not one of a hundred has scaped it, that have proved stayed men afterwards, and very sober husbands; as look you yonder's one may prove, whom now I have in good sooth a great desire to beat.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: In your aunt's presence, and your uncle's house; though I were not his friend; could you be so outrageous? I muse I see him here though.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Cry you mercy sir, are you his friend?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I make myself so, he being dependant to my noblest lord, whom I am bound to honour.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What lord I pray, that I may honour him too.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: The lord lovely.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That loves women above wine, wine above wealth, wealth above friend, and friends above himself. There's no scandal in all that sir.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: It goes so of him indeed, but he loves honour above all those.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Mr. Saveall a word.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Your servant madam.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: In the name of flesh, for what dos his lordship employ that angle-worm to my aunt? He has had her this hour in private conference, close chambered up together, not so much as matron nurse in the room with 'em, 'tis a fine sleek thing, and almost pity to hunt it, but sure I must beat it, as place and time convenient may serve.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Pray Mr. Saveall move you my husband for it, I would not meddle in his money matters willingly.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Five hundred pound for my lord upon the mentioned security, I will break it to sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Is that the business after so much privacy? Very pretty, my ants a woman too, and me uncle may have as forked a fortune, as any of the city, that lend out money to hedge in lordships.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I am his lordship's servant.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And I your lordship's good madam. And yours Mr. Saveall.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I am for your way Mr. Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And I sir, an't please you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: George careless, I would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: May I not wait upon your gentleman to the gate madam?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: No good George, though I commend your courtesy, yet would I not you should neglect your own dignity.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Umh — I am under government.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: The young man, if you have modesty will think you mock him, if not you'll make him become arrogant, know you not whose man he is?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No 'tis apparent, this over-slighting of him proclaims she loves him, whose follower madam, and I know lords followers, knights fellows.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Not all lords followers to all knights George.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: To as many as their fair ladies will give way to, that are not faint-hearted.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I understand you not George; something troubles you, you are not right today.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I am only as I am in your favour madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Come I know what perplexes you ▪ and 'tis therefore that I desire to talk with you; I am not angry with you, but let me tell you George, although not openly I took notice of the pickle you came home in last night, after your uncle was in bed; to whom, marvelling at your absence I excused you, as gone at my request to visit some ladies with whom you stayed supper, I told him, when you were with your roucers.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But did you never go?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Indeed I did, and he was satisfied.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O my sweet lady aunt! I was indeed amongst 'em, and deeply merry.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: And drunk as deeply!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I will abuse your goodness so no more.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Say and hold George, for your own good.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What's now become of me, I am under correction.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I would you could have seen yourself, and how your disguise became you, as I was told, I do but friendly tell you of some passages, as they were to me related, by those whom I have charmed to speak no more on't. Be secure therefore in your uncle.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O my dear heavenly aunt!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: First, at the door you bounced like a giant at the gate of an enchanted castle, before which could be opened offence was taken by you at your sedan-men; for asking money (As appeared afterwards) more than you brought from the tavern, and leaving their office fouler by a distempered stomach-full, than you found it. In the strife for these sad causes your sword being seized on, you being unable to use it, were found by my servants at lugs with your brace of corpse bearers, in the dirt, and their poor hovel chair turned on his ridge in the kennel.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I'll never be drunk again.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I hope you will say so, when you have heard all George; but by the way your late stock being spent, here are ten pieces towards a supply.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O sweet golden aunt!

Well sir, the strife appeased, you were ta'en in. Then hay is there no sack i'the house? 'tis for you in you chamber is replied, up you are had, where is the rogue my man? not seen since yesterday; fetch me a wench. Bless us cries old Sim the butler, we have none i'th house, nor cannot send for any out of doors. Dost — tell me that? is not my lady's woman, my lady's chambermaid, the laundry-maid, the wench under the cook, my lady's nurse old winter plum, nor my lady herself within? I know, or will know all the she things in the house.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: But why me up in your bedroll George?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Pshaw.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You remember none of this!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: It is not worth it madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Nor how you scared chambermaid, whom I sent in love to see care taken for you, not dreaming of any ill thought in you, do you remember how you told her, and what you would give her, when your uncle died for a small present courtesy? she was fain to satisfy you with a false promise to steal to bed to you before four men could force, or humour you into it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What an unhallowed rascal was I!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: 'Tis well you consider it now. And still consider George.
How ill excess of wine, roaring and whoring becomes a gentleman, and how well sobriety, courtesy, and noble action, and dangers wait upon the one sort, and what safety accompanies the other!

sp.speaker: Car.
